title: 108_hr1364
content: The Act may be cited as the "World Trade Center National Memorial Act". On September 11, 2001, terrorists hijacked four civilian aircraft, leading to the deadliest terrorist attack in the United States with nearly 3,000 people killed at the World Trade Center site. Since then, thousands have visited the site to mourn, pay tribute to the heroes, and understand the nature of the attack. The attack on the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001 caused great destruction and loss of jobs and businesses in Lower Manhattan. The emotional toll has been felt worldwide, leading to concerns about the future of the site. Many groups have formed to advocate for the site's recognition as a sacred place. A national memorial is proposed to be established at the World Trade Center site in New York City to commemorate the events of September 11, 2001. The memorial will be designated as a unit of the National Park System, with the purpose of ensuring public access and involvement in its planning and design. The Secretary of the Interior is authorized to provide technical assistance for the memorial's development. The World Trade Center Memorial Advisory Board will provide technical assistance and oversee the management of the national memorial as part of the National Park System. The World Trade Center Memorial Advisory Board will oversee the management of the national memorial as part of the National Park System. SEC. 3 defines key terms. The Act defines key terms such as Board, Corporation, Governor, Mayor, and Memorial related to the World Trade Center Memorial Advisory Board and the rebuilding of the World Trade Center site after the events of September 11, 2001. The Act defines key terms related to the World Trade Center Memorial Advisory Board and the rebuilding of the World Trade Center site in New York City. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 4. WORLD TRADE CENTER NATIONAL MEMORIAL. Establishment of a national memorial at the World Trade Center site in New York City is authorized as a unit of the National Park System. The design and boundary will be determined through a public planning process, with final approval by the Secretary, Governor, and Mayor. Upon transfer of the land to the United States, the Memorial will be administered by the Secretary through the National Park Service. The Corporation will submit a report to the Secretary, Governor, and Mayor within 3 years of the Act's enactment. The report will include the recommended design and boundary for the Memorial, considerations for effective management, a proposal for property transfer to the Secretary, and details on processes and opportunities. The final report, to be submitted within 3 years of the Act's enactment, will include recommendations for the Memorial design and boundary, management considerations, and a proposal for property transfer. Public participation processes, approval procedures, and long-term management issues will also be addressed in the report. The final report, approved by the Secretary, Governor, and Mayor, will be sent to the Senate's Committee on Energy and Natural Resources and the House of Representatives' Committee on Resources. SEC. 6. DUTIES OF THE SECRETARY. The Secretary is authorized to provide assistance for public meetings, project management for planning and construction activities, documentation and interpretation of the site, and acquisition of land for the Memorial site. The Secretary is authorized to provide assistance for public meetings, project management, documentation, interpretation, and land acquisition for the Memorial site. The National Park Service will administer the Memorial as a unit of the National Park System and prepare a charter for the Board to clarify its role and relationship with the Department of the Interior and the National Park Service. Establishment of the World Trade Center Memorial Advisory Board. Establishment of the "World Trade Center Memorial Advisory Board" as an advisory body to the National Park Service for managing the Memorial with input from the public and interested parties. The Board consists of 17 members appointed by the Secretary based on recommendations from Senators, Representatives, and other sources. The "World Trade Center Memorial Advisory Board" consists of 17 members appointed by the Secretary based on recommendations from various sources. Members serve for a 3-year term and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Board designates a Chair and meets regularly, at least 4 times. The Board meets at least 4 times a year, with meeting notices published in local newspapers. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for decision-making, with voting by majority. Board members serve without compensation but are entitled to travel expenses. The Board terminates 60 days after the Memorial is no longer administered by the National Park. The Board terminates 60 days after the Memorial is no longer administered by the National Park Service. Authorization of appropriations for the construction of a permanent Memorial is granted by the Secretary, with funds not exceeding 50% of the construction cost. $300,000 is authorized for technical assistance to the National Park Service annually. The Board is also allocated necessary funds for its responsibilities under this Act.
